messageBody:
Here is a list of books and resources I've found very inspirational
(the numbers indicate an ordening in terms of phases).

Java seems to me one of the most suitable languages for concentrating on
learning OO.

Unit testing and refactoring are also very advisable techniques to use and
know about as soon as possible.

(Furthermore, using ANT and a nice IDE like IntelliJ IDEA should settle you
for a pleasant OO cruise.)

(*) is probably one of the best introductions to OO

a.. book: Design Patterns, (GoF) (2)
b.. book: Craig Larman, "Applying UML and Patterns" (2) (*)
c.. Martin Fowler:
a.. http://martinfowler.com/articles.html
b.. book: "UML Distilled: A Brief Guide to the Standard Object Modeling
Language" (2)
c.. book: "Analysis Patterns : Reusable Object Models" (3)
d.. book: "Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code" (3)
d.. unit testing: http://www.junit.org/ (1)
e.. refactoring: www.refactoring.com (2)
f.. ANT: http://jakarta.apache.org/ant/antnews.html
g.. programming in Java:
h.. book: Bruce Eckel, "Thinking in Java, 2nd Edition (1)
i.. Java @ Sun (1)
AG

Bringing a newbie into OO
=========================

I would like to ask the people on this list for recommendations of the
best
literature to bring an OO newbie up to speed.

The programming language in question is Java, which means that there is a
splendid wealth of online material for someone to learn the language. The
important thing, however, is to instill the notion of OO purity, which is
harder, perhaps, than just teaching the language.

For example: the GoF patterns book is a must, but I think it is not a text
that you can give to someone until they have a grounding in OO techniques.

Your thoughts?

Manuel Amago.

-----------------------------------------------
DISCLAIMER
I know this group is not for this type of question, which is why I
explicitly labelled this thread as OT (Off Topic). I hope you will
forgive
my impertinence. ;)
But, I greatly value the opinions of the people on this list, and I trust
your opinion on this particular issue.
